Such relationships can be harmonious, but they often are problematic. For example, minorities may be generally deprived of police protection and other services to which they are entitled. More specifically, police may refrain from addressing criminal behaviour (e.g., domestic violence) within a particular minority group because they believe that members of that group typically engage in such behaviour. A more acute problem is direct conflict between police and minorities. class="grid">				<div class="grid-sm">					<article id="article-content" class="content"><section id="ref" data-level="1"><section id="ref260928" data-level="2"><h2 class="h2">Police and <span id="ref929834"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/minority" class="md-crosslink">minorities</a></h2><p>The relationships between police and ethnic and racial minorities present some of the more enduring and complex problems in policing throughout the world. Such relationships can be harmonious, but they often are problematic. For example, minorities may be generally deprived of police protection and other services to which they are entitled. More specifically, police may refrain from addressing criminal behaviour (e.g., domestic violence) within a particular <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/minority" class="md-crosslink autoxref">minority group</a> because they believe that members of that group typically engage in such behaviour. A more <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/acute" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="acute">acute</a> problem is direct conflict between police and minorities. On the part of police, conflict may take the form of harassment, brutality, or excessive enforcement.</p><!--[P1]--><p>Although it is no excuse for lack of fairness, police attitudes toward minorities reflect the values of the larger <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/community" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="community">community</a>. When the community is hostile toward a particular minority group, police may feel that <span id="ref929836"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/discrimination-society" class="md-crosslink">discriminatory</a> behaviour toward that group is justified. Police even may aggravate an existing <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/prejudice" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="prejudice">prejudice</a>, though they seldom generate prejudice on their own.</p><!--[P2]--><p>The intensity of community and police prejudice against minority groups depends on historical and social factors. The longer a minority has been seen as inferior or alien, the more likely it is to be discriminated against. Such groups may include <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/perennial" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="perennial">perennial</a> nomads (such as the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/Rom" class="md-crosslink">Roma</a> in Europe), <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/indigenous" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="indigenous">indigenous</a> peoples in former European colonies, or smaller tribes in societies where tribal membership is socially significant. A war or a warlike situation can provoke hostility toward certain immigrant groups or other minorities perceived as the “enemy”: Japanese Americans were treated in this way during <a href="https://www.britannica.com/event/World-War-II" class="md-crosslink autoxref">World War II</a>, as were many Muslims in Western countries after the terrorist <a href="https://www.britannica.com/event/September-11-attacks" class="md-crosslink">September 11 attacks</a> in the United States in 2001. Police <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/discrimination" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="discrimination">discrimination</a> also may occur when the majority of a society perceives a minority group as refusing to <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/endorse" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="endorse">endorse</a> the majority’s values. For instance, the conspicuously inferior status of women in some immigrant <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/communities" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="communities">communities</a> in Western countries has engendered considerable hostility toward the men in those communities. Finally, circumstantial resentment plays an important part in discrimination against minorities: immigrant workers who were welcomed by the majority when work was plentiful may be the target of harassment in periods of unemployment.</p><!--[P3]--><p>Recruitment policies that determine the racial and ethnic makeup of a police force can significantly affect the relationships between the police and minorities. Although it is no guarantee of harmony, it is desirable that the racial and ethnic <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/composition" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="composition">composition</a> of the force reflect that of the larger community. However, that goal is often difficult to achieve. For instance, in large American cities such as Chicago, significant segments of the Hispanic minority speak only Spanish, which precludes their being recruited by the police. The worst-case scenario occurs when the whole police organization is made up of members of a community that is in open conflict with another group. That was the case in the United States during the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/racial-segregation" class="md-crosslink">segregation</a> of African Americans in the South—some police officers actually were members of racist organizations such as the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/Ku-Klux-Klan" class="md-crosslink autoxref">Ku Klux Klan</a>. It was also the case in the late 1960s in <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Northern-Ireland" class="md-crosslink autoxref">Northern Ireland</a>, where despite a provision that the <span id="ref929837"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/Royal-Ulster-Constabulary" class="md-crosslink">Royal Ulster Constabulary</a> (RUC) recruit one-third of its members from among Ulster Catholics, the proportion of Catholics in the force was much smaller than that. The RUC was severely criticized for its brutality in policing the Catholic <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/civil-rights" class="md-crosslink autoxref">civil rights</a> marches in 1968–69. The bias in police recruitment was even worse in <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/South-Africa" class="md-crosslink autoxref">South Africa</a> under <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/apartheid" class="md-crosslink">apartheid</a>, when the police forces were all-white organizations that frequently abused their power in dealings with black South Africans.</p><!--[P4]--><div class="assemblies"><figure data-type="image" class="md-assembly  media-overlay-link print-false" data-assembly-id="61024"><div class="md-assembly-wrapper" data-type="image"><div class="image-wrapper mg"><img src="https://cdn.britannica.com/700x450/96/71296-004-0B8CB497.jpg" big-src="https://cdn.britannica.com/96/71296-004-0B8CB497.jpg" alt="Civil rights demonstrator attacked by a police dog on May 3, 1963, in Birmingham, Alabama.Prompted by the revived Ku Klux Klan and by the quickly organized White Citizens Councils, the general reaction of the white South to the sit-ins and other civil rights demonstrations of the 1960s was violence." data-width="550" data-height="421"></div></div><figcaption><span class="md-assembly-caption">Civil rights demonstrator attacked by a police dog on May 3, 1963, in Birmingham, Alabama.Prompted by the revived Ku Klux Klan and by the quickly organized White Citizens Councils, the general reaction of the white South to the sit-ins and other civil rights demonstrations of the 1960s was violence.</span><cite>Bill Hudson/AP Images</cite></figcaption></figure></div><!--[ML4]--><p>Today, although troublesome relationships between police and minorities remain common, police are increasingly aware of such problems and have taken broad steps to solve them. The community-policing reforms of the late 20th century (<em>see above</em> <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/police/The-professional-crime-fighting-model#ref260922" class="md-crosslink">Community policing</a>), for example, were motivated in part by the desire to reduce conflict with minorities. However, improvements can happen only in societies in which there is police accountability. Without accountability, complaints about police actions may be met with severe reprisals, including the killing of complainants by police officers.</p><!--[P5]--></section><section id="ref36642" data-level="2"><h2 class="h2"><span id="ref929838"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/crowd" class="md-crosslink">Crowds</a> and <span id="ref416785"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/riot" class="md-crosslink">riots</a></h2><p><a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/Collective" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="Collective">Collective</a> violence is one of the most intractable problems of policing. Riots have played a role both in the creation of police forces and in their reform. For instance, frequent and serious rioting in Britain during the 18th century, such as the anti-Catholic Gordon riots of 1780, left a lasting impression on police reformers. The subsequent <a href="https://www.britannica.com/event/Peterloo-Massacre" class="md-crosslink">Peterloo Massacre</a> of 1819, in which cavalry killed 11 protesters and injured several hundred, helped to spur the British government to create the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/Scotland-Yard" class="md-crosslink autoxref">London Metropolitan Police</a> in 1829. Riots also had played a considerable part in the creation of the French police in 1666. By the end of the 20th century, however, many police forces were coming under increasing <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/criticism" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="criticism">criticism</a> for their often brutal methods of controlling crowds.</p><!--[P6]--><span id="ref36642" data-level="2"></span><section id="ref260929" data-level="3"><h2 class="h3">Types of mass events</h2><p>Crowds that have the potential to become violent form for various reasons, including planned political protests; such crowds also may gather spontaneously. The nature of the mass event to be policed determines what kinds of police tactics may or may not succeed.</p><!--[P7]--><p>In democratic countries, political demonstrations have several common features. They generally are structured events, and the courses of marches often are predetermined and negotiated with the police. Political  protests that occur in the <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/context" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="context">context</a> of international events—for example, political summits and meetings of global economic bodies such as the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/World-Trade-Organization" class="md-crosslink">World Trade Organization</a>—differ from national or local political protests in one respect that is important for policing: they bring together groups of protesters that may have different aims. Some groups simply may want their message to be heard; others may aim to disrupt the meeting as much as possible. Although the police may come to an understanding with some protesters, others may generate confrontations despite any attempts at negotiations. Thus, a great deal of <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/collective-violence" class="md-crosslink autoxref">collective violence</a> may accompany meetings of international bodies, as was the case at the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/Asia-Pacific-Economic-Cooperation" class="md-crosslink">Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation</a> summit in Vancouver in 1997; the World Trade Organization meeting in Seattle in 1999; and the Summit of the Americas in <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Quebec" class="md-crosslink autoxref">Quebec</a>, the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/European-Union" class="md-crosslink">European Union</a> summit in Gothenburg (Sweden), and the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/Group-of-Eight" class="md-crosslink autoxref">Group of Eight</a> (G-8) summit in Genoa (Italy) in 2001.</p><!--[P8]--><div class="assemblies"><figure data-type="image" class="md-assembly  media-overlay-link print-false" data-assembly-id="94614"><div class="md-assembly-wrapper" data-type="image"><div class="image-wrapper mg"><img src="https://cdn.britannica.com/700x450/83/97283-004-8EC39E5C.jpg" big-src="https://cdn.britannica.com/83/97283-004-8EC39E5C.jpg" alt="Demonstrator from an anarchist group negotiating with riot police in Helsinki, 2006." data-width="550" data-height="410"></div></div><figcaption><span class="md-assembly-caption">Demonstrator from an anarchist group negotiating with riot police in Helsinki, 2006.</span><cite>AP</cite></figcaption></figure></div><!--[ML8]--><p>Still, political protests and other events that are planned in advance tend to have less potential for violence than spontaneous gatherings. In many cases, riots occur against a backdrop of long-smoldering frustration and anger—e.g., over racial or ethnic discrimination—and are triggered by a single controversial event. Riots in Los Angeles in 1992, for example, were sparked by the acquittal of two police officers on charges stemming from their beating of an <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/African-American" class="md-crosslink autoxref">African American</a> motorist, and in 2005 riots broke out in France (in large suburbs mainly populated by immigrants) after two youths of North African origin were accidentally killed while allegedly running from police.</p><!--[P9]--></section><span id="ref36642" data-level="2"></span><section id="ref260930" data-level="3"><h2 class="h3">Methods of crowd policing</h2><p>Four basic types of organization may police crowds: <span id="ref929839"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/armed-force" class="md-crosslink">military</a> forces, paramilitary forces, militarized police units, and unspecialized police forces. These organizations use primarily two strategies: escalated force and negotiated management.</p><!--[P10]--><div class="assemblies"><figure data-type="image" class="md-assembly  media-overlay-link print-false" data-assembly-id="107082"><div class="md-assembly-wrapper" data-type="image"><div class="image-wrapper mg"><img src="https://cdn.britannica.com/700x450/39/102639-004-DAE1A957.jpg" big-src="https://cdn.britannica.com/39/102639-004-DAE1A957.jpg" alt="Officers of the French State Security Police (Compagnies Républicaines de Sécurité) practicing crowd control." data-width="550" data-height="358"></div></div><figcaption><span class="md-assembly-caption">Officers of the French State Security Police (Compagnies Républicaines de Sécurité) practicing crowd control.</span><cite>© Ministère de l'intérieur-DICOM, France</cite></figcaption></figure></div><!--[ML10]--><p>In many countries, excepting Western-style <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/democracies" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="democracies">democracies</a>, the military, rather than the police, performs crowd control. There are many variants of this model, which differ primarily according to the level of force the military is willing to use. In some countries ruled by dictatorships, such as Iraq under <a href="https://www.britannica.com/biography/Saddam-Hussein" class="md-crosslink autoxref">Ṣaddām Ḥussein</a>, the whole might of the army, including the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/air-force" class="md-crosslink autoxref">air force</a>, has been used to quash any kind of public demonstration against the regime. Other countries in <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Asia" class="md-crosslink autoxref">Asia</a>, Africa, and Central and South America also leave crowd control to the military, though limited resources may prevent the military from mobilizing sophisticated weapons or vast numbers of soldiers. Even in Western democratic countries, governments increasingly call on the military to police crowds, especially in disaster situations—such as the U.S. city of <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/New-Orleans-Louisiana" class="md-crosslink autoxref">New Orleans</a> following <a href="https://www.britannica.com/event/Hurricane-Katrina" class="md-crosslink autoxref">Hurricane Katrina</a> in 2005—and in situations in which rioters are heavily armed.</p><!--[P11]--><p>In some countries, such as <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Germany" class="md-crosslink autoxref">Germany</a>, <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Italy" class="md-crosslink autoxref">Italy</a>, and France, paramilitary forces within the centralized police apparatus are charged with policing crowds. In France, for example, the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/Compagnies-Republicaines-de-Securite" class="md-crosslink autoxref">State Security Police</a> (a component of the National Police) specializes in order maintenance and crowd control. In democratic Anglo-Saxon countries,  militarized police units, embedded within a police force and lacking institutional <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/autonomy" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="autonomy">autonomy</a>, are a common instrument of policing crowds; all large police forces in those countries have such units. Some of their members are officially assigned to other units (e.g., patrol) and are called upon only in cases of emergency. Militarized police units bear various names, such as special weapons and tactics teams (SWAT teams), but their methods of training and operation, as well as their equipment and firepower, are similar.</p><!--[P12]--><p>Small police forces cannot afford special units and have to police crowds on their own. In crisis situations they generally fare badly, as did the municipal forces in various parts of the United States during the 1960s and ’70s when civil rights and <a href="https://www.britannica.com/event/Vietnam-War" class="md-crosslink autoxref">Vietnam War</a> protests were frequent.</p><!--[P13]--><p>The most ancient strategy of crowd control, <span id="ref929841"></span>escalated force (the use of increasing amounts of force until the crowd disperses), still prevails in most countries that have not adopted Western-style <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/democracy" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="democracy">democracy</a>. Even in democracies, however, escalated force was the traditional way of controlling crowds until the 1970s, when the strategy of <span id="ref929842"></span>negotiated management emerged. The success of the latter strategy depends on two key factors: the willingness of the police and the groups involved to negotiate control of the event and, more fundamentally, the availability of group representatives with whom to negotiate. Such people are easily found in cases of domestic political protests and labour unrest, which naturally involve political and union leaders. In the case of international protests, however, negotiating control requires the cooperation of all the groups involved. In general, the greater the perceived threat to the controlling party, the less inclined it will be to negotiate, particularly if the force that it can summon is overwhelming. Although many scholars of policing expected that the strategy of negotiated management would gradually supersede the strategy of escalation of force in Western-style democracies, their belief was belied by numerous violent confrontations between police and protesters at various international meetings held in democratic countries at the beginning of the 21st century.</p><!--[P14]--><p>Meanwhile, a third strategy of crowd control, called <span id="ref929843"></span>command and control, emerged in the United States. Spearheaded by the New York City Police Department, the strategy was basically an updated version of the escalation of force <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/paradigm" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="paradigm">paradigm</a>, with advanced technological underpinnings. The strategy involves the fragmentation of crowds before they may become rioting mobs and the tight control by police of public spaces <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/allocated" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="allocated">allocated</a> to demonstrators. Police may install large concrete and metal barriers, thereby establishing zones where protesters cannot congregate and organize. They also may disperse crowds with nonlethal weapons, some of which are based on sophisticated technology—for example, the Active Denial System (ADS), which projects a strong blast of heat into a crowd. In addition, police may use electronic surveillance to monitor a crowd’s size and movements, and they may make preemptive arrests of protest leaders or potential troublemakers.</p><!--[P15]--><span class="md-signature"><a href="/contributor/Michael-Parker-Banton/164">Michael Parker Banton</a></span><span class="md-signature"><a href="/contributor/William-Francis-Walsh/5508">William Francis Walsh</a></span><span class="md-signature"><a href="/contributor/Jean-Paul-Brodeur/6354">Jean-Paul Brodeur</a></span></section></section><section id="ref260931" data-level="2"><h2 class="h2"><span id="ref929845"></span>High policing: the protection of <span id="ref929844"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/national-security" class="md-crosslink">national security</a></h2><p>In continental <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Europe" class="md-crosslink autoxref">Europe</a>, police work that is directed at protecting national security is known as high policing, in reference to the “higher” interests of the state. There is no conventional <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/designation" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="designation">designation</a> for this category of policing in Anglo-Saxon countries, however. Calling it “secret” or “political” policing would be too vague, as all police work is to a certain extent both secret (police generally do not reveal their methods until a case is completed) and political (police enforce laws determined by the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/political-system" class="md-crosslink autoxref">political system</a> in power). Furthermore, the term <em>secret police</em> is usually used to refer to <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/clandestine" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="clandestine">clandestine</a> and extralegal organizations like the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/Gestapo" class="md-crosslink">Gestapo</a>, whose main functions are to eliminate opponents of the regime and to make the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/population-biology-and-anthropology" class="md-crosslink autoxref">population</a> passive through intimidation and terror. Whatever it may be called, high policing in Anglo-Saxon countries is performed by both national police forces and specialized agencies, such as the FBI and the Secret Service in the <span id="ref929948"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/United-States" class="md-crosslink">United States</a>, <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/MI5" class="md-crosslink">MI5</a> in the United Kingdom, the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation, the Canadian Security Intelligence Service, and the New Zealand Security Intelligence Service. These organizations usually confront domestic or internal threats to national security, whereas the military or military-intelligence agencies generally handle foreign or external threats. This distinction can become blurred, however, especially in cases involving terrorism. For example, after the September 11 attacks of 2001, José Padilla, a U.S. citizen accused of being an <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/al-Qaeda" class="md-crosslink">al-Qaeda</a> operative, was arrested by the FBI but detained by the U.S. military as an “enemy combatant.”</p><!--[P16]--><p>The primary tool of high policing is <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/intelligence-international-relations" class="md-crosslink">intelligence</a>, which is derived from both human and technological sources, the latter including electronic surveillance and eavesdropping. In the former country of <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/German-Democratic-Republic" class="md-crosslink autoxref">East Germany</a>, the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/Stasi" class="md-crosslink">Stasi</a>, the state <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/secret-police" class="md-crosslink autoxref">secret police</a> agency, relied on vast numbers of informers for intelligence on the activities of East German citizens; the extent of the cooperation it obtained was so great that it tore the social fabric of the country apart when the agency’s files were opened to the public after the fall of the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/Berlin-Wall" class="md-crosslink autoxref">Berlin Wall</a> in 1989. In the United States the <span id="ref929850"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/USA-PATRIOT-Act" class="md-crosslink">USA PATRIOT Act</a> of 2001 (formally, the Uniting and Strengthening America by Providing Appropriate Tools Required to Intercept and Obstruct Terrorism Act) allowed for expanded domestic electronic surveillance of both U.S. citizens and foreign residents, including by means of roving wiretaps and the seizure of voice-mail messages. In a provision that maintained the traditional high-policing function of monitoring the circulation of ideas in society, the PATRIOT Act also allowed <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/law" class="md-crosslink autoxref">law</a> enforcement and intelligence agencies to obtain the library borrowing records of individuals without their knowledge.</p><!--[P17]--><p>Because organizations involved in high policing tend to be granted extensive legal powers, there is a tendency, even in democratic countries, for such organizations to abuse their powers or even to operate outside the law. In some countries, for example, high-policing organizations regularly engage in actions of dubious legality, such as detaining people without charge, without legal representation, and without means of communication; some high-policing forces also engage in <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/torture" class="md-crosslink">torture</a>. In the worst cases, high policing becomes a substitute for the whole <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/criminal-justice" class="md-crosslink autoxref">criminal justice</a> system: suspects are arrested, tried, convicted, and sentenced by a national security agency, usually very expeditiously and in complete secrecy. Concerns about the possibility of such abuses in the United States and Canada prompted many investigations into the national security services of those countries in the 1960s and later. A report commissioned by the Canadian government in 1966 supported these concerns, concluding that “a security service will inevitably be involved in actions that may contravene the spirit if not the letter of the law, and with clandestine and other activities which may sometimes seem to infringe on [an] individual’s rights.” In the early 21st century, particularly in the period that followed the September 11 attacks, some U.S. citizens were held in <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/preventive-detention" class="md-crosslink autoxref">preventive detention</a> in jails, and many foreign nationals were imprisoned without charge at the U.S. naval base at <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Guantanamo-Bay" class="md-crosslink autoxref">Guantánamo Bay</a>, Cuba. Some critics, including the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/United-Nations" class="md-crosslink autoxref">United Nations</a>, claimed that the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/interrogation" class="md-crosslink autoxref">interrogation</a> techniques used on prisoners at Guantánamo amounted to torture.</p><!--[P18]--><p>The most <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/egregious" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="egregious">egregious</a> high-policing abuses occur in countries ruled by <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/authoritarian" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="authoritarian">authoritarian</a> or totalitarian regimes. High-policing organizations in such countries tend to have the following characteristics in common. First, they are accountable not to elected officials but only to the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/executive-government" class="md-crosslink autoxref">executive</a> power. Second, they possess, and in fact are dominated by, a large military wing. (This is a crucial feature: Tsar Nicholas I’s <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/Third-Department" class="md-crosslink">Third Department</a> of secret police relied on a huge body of gendarmes to execute its repressive operations; the Gestapo was a part of the Reich Security Central Office, which was supported by battalions of <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/SS" class="md-crosslink">SS</a> troops; and the Soviet <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/NKVD" class="md-crosslink">NKVD</a> under <a href="https://www.britannica.com/biography/Joseph-Stalin" class="md-crosslink autoxref">Joseph Stalin</a> was both a political police force and a military corps.) Third, the military wings maintain their own penal administration and control a network of detention facilities (most often <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/concentration-camp" class="md-crosslink">concentration camps</a>). Fourth, these organizations systematically resort to torture, which is applied without concern for the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/human-rights" class="md-crosslink autoxref">human rights</a> or even the lives of the victims.</p><!--[P19]--><p>The wide extent of such practices should not be taken to show that protecting national security requires gross violations of human rights. On the contrary, in most democratic countries the conduct of high policing, when subject to proper oversight, does not contradict democratic values or infringe upon basic civil or human rights.</p><!--[P20]--><span class="md-signature"><a href="/contributor/Jean-Paul-Brodeur/6354">Jean-Paul Brodeur</a></span></section><section id="ref36643" data-level="2"><h2 class="h2">Police work as an occupation</h2><p>Public policing used to be a low-status and underpaid occupation. Until modern times, police recruits typically had no qualifications other than military service; thugs and former criminals also were hired, in keeping with the common beliefs that “it takes a thief to catch a thief” and that one need not be educated to wield a stick. (In 19th-century France a former convict, <a href="https://www.britannica.com/biography/Francois-Eugene-Vidocq" class="md-crosslink">François Vidocq</a>, rose to the position of chief of the public safety brigade, whose mission was to infiltrate the criminal <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/milieus" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="milieus">milieus</a> and to <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/arrest" class="md-crosslink autoxref">arrest</a> <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/notorious" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="notorious">notorious</a> offenders.) Not surprisingly, underpaying the police resulted in massive corruption, particularly in the urban police forces of the United States at the beginning of the 20th century. Today, police corruption remains a severe problem in countries where policing is still considered a lowly occupation—that is, in almost every country except the Western-style democracies (including Japan). In the latter countries, 20th-century reformers transformed policing into a professional occupation that commanded decent wages and public respect. Careers in these police forces can even be lucrative, especially for those in the top echelons. In <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/North-America" class="md-crosslink autoxref">North America</a>, police recruits of large-city police forces can embark on their careers in their early 20s and retire in their early 50s as top managers with sizable pensions. Many then undertake new careers as chiefs of small-town police forces, as officials in other public-service departments, or as managers of private security companies.</p><!--[P21]--><p>The police recruiting system used in Anglo-Saxon countries differs from that used in continental Europe. In such countries as the United States, the United Kingdom, Australia, Canada, and New Zealand, nearly all recruits enter at the lowest level of the organization, regardless of their educational background. They may be promoted during their career on the basis of performance <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/assessments" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="assessments">assessments</a> and competitive examinations. In the United Kingdom the most able among the younger officers are selected for a 12-month course at the national police training college at Bramshill, where they divide their time between on-the-job training and study. However, training at Bramshill does not guarantee promotion, and Bramshill graduates who subsequently join other police forces still must start at the bottom of those organizations.</p><!--[P22]--><p>The situation is different in continental Europe, particularly in France, where police forces use a dual system of recruitment: entrants may start their careers at the base of the organization and progressively rise higher, or they may use lateral entry for an appointment at the <em>commissaire</em> (“commissioner”) level. The channel of lateral entry is reserved for applicants with a university degree, generally in law or political science; after their selection, they are trained at the national academy for police commissioners.</p><!--[P23]--><p>Lateral entry is the rule for the highest positions in the police organizations of both continental Europe and North America. In France the government directly appoints the chief of the National Police, who may be a civil servant without a police background. In Canada and the United States, chiefs of police or their top assistants are directly appointed by the relevant political authority. After the September 11 attacks, the New York City Police Department directly appointed persons from the intelligence community and the armed forces to head its intelligence and counterterrorism departments.</p><!--[P24]--><p>Most police forces are <span id="ref929861"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/organized-labor" class="md-crosslink">unionized</a>, though there are important exceptions—e.g., the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/Royal-Canadian-Mounted-Police" class="md-crosslink">Royal Canadian Mounted Police</a>, the largest Canadian police force. As in the case of recruitment, there are two basic models for police unions, one used in Anglo-Saxon countries and the other used in continental Europe.</p><!--[P25]--><p>In many Anglo-Saxon countries, or in some jurisdictions within those countries, police unions have long been forbidden. To <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/circumvent" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="circumvent">circumvent</a> such prohibitions, police in these areas created brotherhoods, <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/benevolent" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="benevolent">benevolent</a> organizations, and other associations that performed the role of a labour union. As a result, for most police forces in the Anglo-Saxon tradition, there is a single body acting as a union to which both rank-and-file personnel and their supervisors belong. In periods of conflict with top managers—who usually are not members of the labour association—mid-level officers must choose between their duty to obey the top managers and their loyalty to the labour association; usually they choose the latter. The customary alliance between rank-and-file officers and their supervisors has given such associations considerable clout; little change can be effected in police forces without at least their partial assent. Police associations in the United States also act as brokers in the private employment of public police. For example, organizers of large events might ask the police association to provide a certain number of police officers to keep order. The officers are then compensated on a private basis through the association.</p><!--[P26]--><p>In continental Europe the tradition of organized labour is much older. Governments did not oppose the creation of police unions, which were modeled on existing unions in industry and some professions. As a result, rank-and-file police do not generally belong to the same association as their supervisors; in France, for example, there are separate unions for the rank and file and for commissioners. It is actually in <span id="ref929863"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/France" class="md-crosslink">France</a> that the <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/incipient" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="incipient">incipient</a> forms of police labour unions first appeared. In 1855 police commissioners stated their demands regarding working conditions in the <em>Journal des commissaires</em>. French commissioners finally created an official labour organization to represent them in 1906. It is one of the oldest police unions, if not the oldest.</p><!--[P27]--><span class="md-signature"><a href="/contributor/Jean-Paul-Brodeur/6354">Jean-Paul Brodeur</a></span></section></section><!--[H7]--><section id="ref260932" data-level="1"><h2 class="h1"><span id="ref416588"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/police-technology" class="md-crosslink">Police technology</a></h2><p>Police technology refers to the wide range of scientific and technological methods, techniques, and equipment used in policing. As science has advanced, so too have the technologies that police rely upon to prevent crime and apprehend criminals. Police technology was recognized as a distinct academic and scientific <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/discipline" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="discipline">discipline</a> in the 1960s, and since then a growing body of professional literature, educational programs, workshops, and international conferences has been devoted to the technological aspects of police work.</p><!--[P28]--><p>Many examples of an incipient police technology date from ancient and <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/medieval" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="medieval">medieval</a> times. <span id="ref"></span>For example, the ancient Egyptians used detailed word descriptions of individuals, a concept known in modern times as <em>portrait parlé</em> (French: “spoken portrait”), and the Babylonians pressed <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/fingerprint" class="md-crosslink">fingerprints</a> into clay to identify the author of <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/cuneiform" class="md-crosslink">cuneiform</a> writings and to protect against <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/forgery-law" class="md-crosslink">forgery</a>. Nevertheless, early technology was quite crude, such as the medieval methods of <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/trial-law" class="md-crosslink autoxref">trial</a> by <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/ordeal" class="md-crosslink">ordeal</a> and trial by combat, in which the innocence of suspects was established by their survival. A more humane medieval method, and a step toward modern concepts, was <span id="ref416589"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/compurgation" class="md-crosslink">compurgation</a>, in which the friends and families of a disputant took oaths not on the facts but on the disputant’s character. Formalized police departments were established in the late 17th century in continental Europe, and since that time technologies have developed rapidly—transforming police work into a more scientific endeavour.</p><!--[P29]--><p>Yet police technology differs greatly in type and sophistication from country to country. It is generally more sophisticated in countries that are wealthy and that produce or import a high level of technology. (However, undemocratic countries tend to invest a great share of their <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/gross-national-product" class="md-crosslink autoxref">gross national product</a> in police technology, even when they are poor.) Police technology also depends on the physical setting and the political <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/environment" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="environment">environment</a> where police work is done. Urban policing relies more on technology than small-town and rural policing, and the degree to which a police force is militarized has a strong impact on its weaponry. Finally, some newer crimes, such as <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/cybercrime" class="md-crosslink">cybercrime</a>, can be fought only by using an extensive array of technology that exceeds the scope of police technology proper.</p><!--[P30]--><section id="ref260934" data-level="2"><h2 class="h2">Mobility</h2><p>To be effective, police forces must be in close proximity to the citizens they serve. The first and most basic means of maintaining that close contact was the foot <span id="ref416597"></span>patrol. Officers were <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/deployed" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="deployed">deployed</a> by time of day (watches) and area (beats). Beats were kept geographically small to allow officers to respond to incidents in a timely manner. In larger rural jurisdictions, officers were deployed on horseback. Both foot and mounted patrols continue to be used throughout the world. Foot patrol is used in congested urban areas, in high-density housing complexes, and at special events; mounted patrol is also used for special events and for crowd control.</p><!--[P31]--><div class="assemblies"><figure data-type="image" class="md-assembly  media-overlay-link print-false" data-assembly-id="95195"><div class="md-assembly-wrapper" data-type="image"><div class="image-wrapper mg"><img src="https://cdn.britannica.com/700x450/67/98467-004-49FEECE0.jpg" big-src="https://cdn.britannica.com/67/98467-004-49FEECE0.jpg" alt="Officers of the New York City Police Department and their various means of transportation." data-width="550" data-height="433"></div></div><figcaption><span class="md-assembly-caption">Officers of the New York City Police Department and their various means of transportation.</span><cite>Courtesy of the New York City Police Department</cite></figcaption></figure></div><!--[ML31]--><p>Foot and mounted patrols were followed by <span id="ref929865"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/bicycle" class="md-crosslink">bicycle</a> patrol, which spread throughout continental Europe at the end of the 19th century. Bicycle patrol made a comeback in the late 20th and early 21st centuries as a compromise between foot and car patrols. Bicycle patrol officers are specially trained and equipped with <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/robust" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="robust">robust</a> but lightweight urban bicycles. Bicycles are very useful for patrolling urban parks, housing complexes, school campuses, and locations where there are multiple large walkways not immediately accessible from the street.</p><!--[P32]--><p>The development of the <span id="ref929866"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/automobile" class="md-crosslink">automobile</a> in the late 19th century dramatically transformed police work in the early 20th century. The city of <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Akron-Ohio" class="md-crosslink">Akron</a>, <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Ohio-state" class="md-crosslink">Ohio</a>, U.S., claims to have deployed the first automobile police patrol wagon in 1899. The vehicle was powered by an electric <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/battery-electronics" class="md-crosslink">battery</a>, however, which greatly limited its range over distances. A <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/motorcycle" class="md-crosslink">motorcycle</a> patrol was instituted in New York City in 1905. By 1910 in <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/France" class="md-crosslink">France</a>, 12 regional mobile brigades of police had become fully motorized; they used gasoline-powered automobiles manufactured by the De Dion-Bouton company to crisscross France. The motorization of police forces took place simultaneously in virtually all Western countries; by <a href="https://www.britannica.com/event/World-War-I" class="md-crosslink autoxref">World War I</a>, many urban police departments were using motorized patrols. Automobiles allowed police to expand patrol beats and reduced the time required for responding to incidents. However, the mobility and speed that police cruisers provided came at the expense of police visibility, as officers were increasingly <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/encapsulated" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="encapsulated">encapsulated</a> in their cars.</p><!--[P33]--><p>The police cruiser played a bigger role in the cities of the New World—<a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Australia" class="md-crosslink">Australia</a>, <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Canada" class="md-crosslink">Canada</a>, <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/New-Zealand" class="md-crosslink">New Zealand</a>, and the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/United-States" class="md-crosslink">United States</a>—than elsewhere. New World cities generally were laid out in a gridlike pattern with large intersecting avenues that <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/facilitated" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="facilitated">facilitated</a> motorized police patrols. By contrast, European cities typically featured a maze of small, crowded streets that required foot patrols. The equipment carried by the standard police vehicle in these New World cities significantly evolved from the 1970s to the early 21st century. In the 1970s the police car was basically the same as the mass-produced vehicles owned by citizens. It was fitted with few accessories for <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/enhancing" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="enhancing">enhancing</a> comfort, such as air conditioning, and the specific police equipment that it carried consisted of a two-way radio with limited capacities and an external rotating light fitted on its roof; a metal screen between the front and the back seats was common but not standard. By the 21st century, the modern big-city patrol vehicle was routinely fitted with heavy-duty alternators to power numerous electronic devices and a powerful <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/cooling-system" class="md-crosslink autoxref">cooling system</a> to handle engine heat while idling during hot weather. It also was equipped with an array of electronic devices, including radios, siren and light controls, a public-address system, a <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/cell-phone" class="md-crosslink autoxref">cellular telephone</a>, a radar unit to measure motorists’ speed, and, in many jurisdictions, a mobile digital terminal for access to police databases. Even the trunk was filled with equipment, such as first-aid and biohazard-response kits. Like the police vehicle itself, such equipment reflects the technologies produced by domestic industries. In countries whose industrial sectors are large and technologically advanced, such as the United States, Germany, and Japan, police cruisers tend to be very sophisticated instruments; elsewhere, they are more <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/rudimentary" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="rudimentary">rudimentary</a>.</p><!--[P34]--><p>The array of duties performed by police today requires a variety of different vehicles, ranging from minicars to buses and fully equipped mobile headquarters. For example, traffic-law enforcement is often conducted by patrol officers on motorcycles, but cars also are commonly used. In the United States, police often drive sport-utility vehicles (SUVs) for highway patrol. Police cruisers are generally smaller in Europe and Japan than in the United States and Canada, reflecting the standards of domestic auto industries. In Germany and Italy, police may use sophisticated sports cars, such as Porsches, BMWs, and even Ferraris, for high-speed chases.</p><!--[P35]--><ul class="assemblies medialist" data-type="other"><li><figure data-type="image" class="md-assembly  media-overlay-link print-false" data-assembly-id="107086"><div class="md-assembly-wrapper" data-type="image"><div class="image-wrapper mg"><img src="https://cdn.britannica.com/700x450/24/102624-004-AB7DB744.jpg" big-src="https://cdn.britannica.com/24/102624-004-AB7DB744.jpg" alt="Police officer using radar to check motorists' speed, France." data-width="329" data-height="450"></div></div><figcaption><span class="md-assembly-caption">Police officer using radar to check motorists' speed, France.</span><cite>© Ministère de l'intérieur-DICOM, France</cite></figcaption></figure></li><li><figure data-type="image" class="md-assembly  media-overlay-link print-false" data-assembly-id="95196"><div class="md-assembly-wrapper" data-type="image"><div class="image-wrapper mg"><img src="https://cdn.britannica.com/700x450/69/98469-004-604A4E3F.jpg" big-src="https://cdn.britannica.com/69/98469-004-604A4E3F.jpg" alt="Truck from the 1930s (left) used by the New York City Police Department (NYPD) next to a contemporary truck used by the NYPD Emergency Service Unit." data-width="550" data-height="435"></div></div><figcaption><span class="md-assembly-caption">Truck from the 1930s (left) used by the New York City Police Department (NYPD) next to a contemporary truck used by the NYPD Emergency Service Unit.</span><cite>Courtesy of the New York City Police Department</cite></figcaption></figure></li></ul><!--[ML35]--><p>Some police vehicles have been adapted from military vehicles. Police in South Africa use the Buffel, a vehicle derived from an armoured personnel carrier, and the Police Service of Northern Ireland (formerly the Royal Ulster Constabulary) uses military vehicles in its patrols. In the United States, some police departments have converted armoured scout vehicles to assist in high-risk operations. Vehicles built on large chassis can be used to transport a fully equipped command centre to a crime scene or disaster area.</p><!--[P36]--><p>The environment is another factor that determines the types of vehicles used by police forces. In many rural jurisdictions the typical four-door sedan has been replaced by SUVs and four-wheel-drive trucks. In areas where there are no paved roads (e.g., open country, beaches, and forests), the police use all-terrain vehicles and off-road motorcycles. Snowmobiles and tracked vehicles are used in areas where large snow accumulations are typical.</p><!--[P37]--><p>Police departments that patrol waterfronts employ small to midsize open-cockpit motorboats. Customs and border-surveillance agencies have access to some of the most complex and exotic <span id="ref929936"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/watercraft" class="md-crosslink">watercraft</a> to combat illicit drug-running and border incursions. In areas with large swamps, the police use airboats (flat-bottomed boat hulls with an aircraft engine and propeller for propulsion).</p><!--[P38]--><div class="assemblies"><figure data-type="image" class="md-assembly  media-overlay-link print-false" data-assembly-id="95197"><div class="md-assembly-wrapper" data-type="image"><div class="image-wrapper mg"><img src="https://cdn.britannica.com/700x450/70/98470-004-762ECD31.jpg" big-src="https://cdn.britannica.com/70/98470-004-762ECD31.jpg" alt="Boat belonging to the Harbor Unit of the New York City Police Department patrolling the city's waterfront." data-width="550" data-height="401"></div></div><figcaption><span class="md-assembly-caption">Boat belonging to the Harbor Unit of the New York City Police Department patrolling the city's waterfront.</span><cite>Courtesy of the New York City Police Department</cite></figcaption></figure></div><!--[ML38]--><p>Various types of <span id="ref929867"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/aircraft" class="md-crosslink">aircraft</a> are used in police patrols as well. Helicopters, the most common type, are often equipped with a high-intensity spotlight that can provide overhead illumination for units on the ground. Another device used by aircraft, a passive infrared unit sometimes called <span id="ref929939"></span>forward-looking infrared (FLIR), provides night vision. FLIR units can measure the heat energy emitted by objects and living things, enabling ground units to be directed to a particular location. The police also employ fixed-wing aircraft for operations such as border patrols and drug surveillance, police-personnel transport over long distances, and highway <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/traffic-control" class="md-crosslink autoxref">traffic control</a>. They range in size from single-seat planes to multiengine jet aircraft.</p><!--[P39]--><div class="assemblies"><figure data-type="image" class="md-assembly  media-overlay-link print-false" data-assembly-id="51212"><div class="md-assembly-wrapper" data-type="image"><div class="image-wrapper mg"><img src="https://cdn.britannica.com/700x450/58/60758-004-6DF84955.jpg" big-src="https://cdn.britannica.com/58/60758-004-6DF84955.jpg" alt="Bell Helicopter Textron 206B-3 JetRanger III civil helicopter, in police service, Fort Worth, Texas, U.S." data-width="550" data-height="258"></div></div><figcaption><span class="md-assembly-caption">Bell Helicopter Textron 206B-3 JetRanger III civil helicopter, in police service, Fort Worth, Texas, U.S.</span><cite>©  1998 Textron All Rights Reserved.</cite></figcaption></figure></div><!--[ML39]--></section><section id="ref36583" data-level="2"><h2 class="h2"><span id="ref416591"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/communication-system" class="md-crosslink">Communication</a></h2><p>The vehicles discussed above would be nothing more than efficient <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/conveyances" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="conveyances">conveyances</a> if police officers were unable to communicate instantly with each other and the public. In the earliest police forces, communication was accomplished through oral or written orders in an administrative chain of command. As society progressed, the military was used less for domestic peacekeeping. Depending on whether a country evolved toward more or less centralization, systems of national or local control were established. In <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/England" class="md-crosslink autoxref">England</a> the <span id="ref929940"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/watch-and-ward-system" class="md-crosslink">watch-and-ward system</a> evolved to provide citizens with protection from crime. During times of duress, the men on watch would raise the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/hue-and-cry" class="md-crosslink">hue and cry</a> to summon assistance from the citizens of the community or, in the case of a larger community, from others already on watch. The watch standers were equipped with various signaling devices, including bells, ratchets, and rattles.</p><!--[P40]--><div class="assemblies"><figure data-type="image" class="md-assembly  media-overlay-link print-false" data-assembly-id="107098"><div class="md-assembly-wrapper" data-type="image"><div class="image-wrapper mg"><img src="https://cdn.britannica.com/700x450/35/102635-004-F5A0EC4B.jpg" big-src="https://cdn.britannica.com/35/102635-004-F5A0EC4B.jpg" alt="Police officer using the radio in his patrol vehicle." data-width="293" data-height="450"></div></div><figcaption><span class="md-assembly-caption">Police officer using the radio in his patrol vehicle.</span><cite>© Ministère de l'intérieur-DICOM, France</cite></figcaption></figure></div><!--[ML40]--><p>With the passage of the Metropolitan Police Act in 1829, the police in England were formalized into a full-time paid service, as they had been in France, <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Austria" class="md-crosslink autoxref">Austria</a>, and <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Prussia" class="md-crosslink autoxref">Prussia</a>. The system was directed by a central command through face-to-face contact between supervisors and subordinates. As urban areas expanded and the police were deployed to more beats over larger geographic areas, this system of human communication became increasingly inefficient. Face-to-face contact gave way to the use of <span id="ref416592"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/telecommunication" class="md-crosslink">telegraphs</a> in the mid-19th century, and in the late 1870s police departments began installing telephone systems. In urban jurisdictions call boxes, or street telephones, were placed on beats to enable patrol officers and citizens to alert the central command of disturbances. In 1937 the first emergency telephone system was established in <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/London" class="md-crosslink autoxref">London</a>, where callers could dial 999 to speak to an operator.</p><!--[P41]--><p>Early systems of police dispatch involved a single operator who took calls from the public and dispatched officers via <span id="ref929942"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/radio" class="md-crosslink">radio</a>. In 1917 the police department of <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/New-York-City" class="md-crosslink">New York City</a> began equipping patrol vehicles with a one-way radio receiver that enabled the central command to send emergency messages to officers. However, that and other early radio-communications systems were fraught with technical problems. In 1928, following several years of experimentation, the police department of Detroit improved the technology to allow regular contact between headquarters and patrol units; the system developed in Detroit was subsequently the basis of police communications systems used throughout the United States. Two-way radio receivers were first deployed in 1933 in Bayonne, N.J., and their use proliferated in the 1940s. Radios in patrol cars were eventually supplemented by portable radio transceivers carried by individual officers to allow uninterrupted radio contact between officers and the dispatch centre. Dispatch was improved in the United States in the late 1960s with the establishment of the 911 emergency telephone system. Similar systems have since been adopted in other countries throughout the world.</p><!--[P42]--><div class="assemblies"><figure data-type="image" class="md-assembly  media-overlay-link print-false" data-assembly-id="108656"><div class="md-assembly-wrapper" data-type="image"><div class="image-wrapper mg"><img src="https://cdn.britannica.com/700x450/44/102644-004-1B693481.jpg" big-src="https://cdn.britannica.com/44/102644-004-1B693481.jpg" alt="Officers of the French National Police at a command post." data-width="550" data-height="358"></div></div><figcaption><span class="md-assembly-caption">Officers of the French National Police at a command post.</span><cite>© Ministère de l'intérieur-DICOM, France</cite></figcaption></figure></div><!--[ML42]--><p>Police radio-communications systems benefited from the development of computers, which made possible the quick retrieval of information on stolen property, wanted persons, and other police intelligence. <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/computer" class="md-crosslink">Computers</a> were eventually placed in patrol cars. These mobile digital terminals (MDTs) enable officers to check licenses, wanted-persons lists, and warrants from the patrol vehicle without making an oral radio transmission. MDTs have been supplemented with a wide variety of digital pagers and cellular phones.</p><!--[P43]--></section><section id="ref36582" data-level="2"><h2 class="h2"><span id="ref416626"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/computer" class="md-crosslink">Computerization</a></h2><p>The police were early adopters of computer <span id="ref929944"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/database" class="md-crosslink">database</a> technology. In the United States the <span id="ref929943"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/National-Crime-Information-Center" class="md-crosslink">National Crime Information Center</a> (NCIC) was established in 1967; police records were subsequently computerized and made available to police agencies throughout the country. The NCIC’s database enables local police departments to apprehend offenders who might otherwise evade capture. The database contains fingerprints, a registry of sexual offenders, and mug shots, and it can be queried for detailed information on stolen vehicles and warrants for firearms violations; it can even search for phonetically similar names. Similar databases maintained by U.S. states provide police with access to misdemeanour warrants, driver-citation records, and vehicle-ownership information.</p><!--[P44]--><p>The <span id="ref929947"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/European-Union" class="md-crosslink">European Union</a> (EU) established a computerized information system—the <span id="ref929945"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/Schengen-Information-System" class="md-crosslink">Schengen Information System</a> (SIS)—which allows the authorities of certain member states, plus some other European countries, to send or receive data about criminals, missing persons, stolen <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/property-legal-concept" class="md-crosslink">property</a>, and other matters of interest to law enforcement officers. Each member of the EU, however, must devise its own computerized system to connect to the SIS. The European Police Office (Europol) also maintains a computerized database. In addition, <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/Interpol" class="md-crosslink">Interpol</a> manages databases of <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/fingerprint" class="md-crosslink">fingerprints</a>, DNA profiles, and information on stolen property and other matters, which member countries can retrieve through a global police- communications system known as I-24/7.</p><!--[P45]--><p><span id="ref929949"></span>Computer-assisted-dispatch (CAD) systems, such as the 911 system in the United States, are used not only to dispatch police quickly in an emergency but also to gather data on every person who has contact with the police. Information in the CAD database generally includes call volume, time of day, types of calls, response time, and the <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/disposition" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="disposition">disposition</a> of every call. The <span id="ref929950"></span>Enhanced 911 (E911) system, adopted in the United States, instantly identifies the number of the phone from which the call is made, as well as the name and physical address of the person who owns the phone. Data maintained in the E911 system sometimes include a history of calls to the police from the caller’s location. When the CAD system is linked to a global positioning system (<a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/GPS" class="md-crosslink">GPS</a>), dispatchers can immediately identify the police cruiser nearest the scene of the emergency.</p><!--[P46]--><p>Although records are essential for effective police operations, police departments would be overwhelmed without a mechanism for filtering information and making sense of it. Police have long been able to gather information from related cases by using whatever records were available to them, but, until the advent of computerized databases, such cases could be found only through the recollection of experienced investigators. Computerized records systems can be extremely effective in drawing out relationships between past and present cases and suspects. The computer acts like a seasoned detective with an encyclopaedic memory. Systems known as Compstat (<em>see above</em> <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/police/The-professional-crime-fighting-model#ref260923" class="md-crosslink">Compstat</a>), used by a variety of large cities, enable police departments to piece together information and to <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/deploy" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="deploy">deploy</a> personnel efficiently.</p><!--[P47]--></section></section><nav class="prev-next-pagination margin-top-50 margin-bottom-50 grid no-gutter has-previous has-next">        <div class="pagination-control
